description.narrative: Protected Areas Network Management and Capacity Building in the Republic of South Sudan

Environment - policy, planning and administration

receiver-org.narrative: Government of South Sudan, Republic of

description.narrative: Secure the foundation for biodiversity conservation in the post conflict development of Southern Sudan through enhanced management effectiveness of the protected areas estate
Number of management plans and preliminary management strategies

comment.narrative: 8,504,500 ha total PA coverage (on paper) and 2,000,000 ha PA under improved management
8,854,500 ha total PA coverage and 6,800,000 ha PA under improved management

Total PA coverage 8,504,500 ha. PA area under improved management estimated at 6,000,000 ha. (2.5 million hectares in Boma, 2 million hectares in Badingilo and about 1.5 million hectares in Southern). Protected Area under improved management has expanded with establishment of wildlife headquarters, ranger posts, administrative blocks and garages in Boma, Badingilo and Southern National Park. Badingilo Management plan draft completed awaiting stakeholders consultations. With a new Park Warden installed and a fleet of vehicles and a set of communications equipment to undertake operations, wildlife management activities in Boma National Park have been scaled up given the relative instability in Boma and surrounding areas.

description.narrative: Financial sustainability score (%) for PAs

comment.narrative:
Clear mandates have been developed for the Wildlife Service regarding PA finances. Partners are working closely with the government to support and increase PA budget and address issues to do with financing gap. Clear policies have been developed promoting budgeting for protected areas. The protected area management plans have included financial data to aid planning and have provided clear indications of running cost of the protected areas. The Wildlife and Tourism policies and Bills promote concessions in protected areas. Tourism Masterplan has been developed detailing the full range of tourism potentials across the country. The concept note for the Conservation Financing has been updated.
The plans for development of sustainable financing mechanisms for protected areas are in place to undertake an expert assessment of the various funding potentials and financing mechanisms including carbon sequestration (REDD+), ecosystems services, trust funds, ecotourism, conservation easements from oil and mineral companies. Tourism regulations have been developed and updated to regulate eco-tourism activities. Levies for site-based revenues options such as tourism entrance fees, tourism permits, hotel levies and concessions have been developed and integrated into the regulations. Nimule National Park has started using the fee structure to receive limited tourists as the area is relatively stable. Other options such as debt-for-nature swaps through which funding could be galvanized for protected areas management across the country are being explored. Nonetheless the security situations across the country have slowed down the realization of the tourism potentials and this security dynamics will continued to be monitored.

description.narrative:
Capacity development indicator score (%) for PA network: Systemic Institutional
Individual

comment.narrative:
At Systemic level, the work plans development has been prioritized for Lantoto, and Southern National Parks (both covering North eastern Sector in the Lakes State and Western Sector in Western Equatoria State), Boma and Badingilo Parks. As part of the capacity development in work planning, individual Park Wardens and representative of these areas worked with WCSs protected area expert to introduce the Wardens to work planning process and designs. These work plans were specially designed to address coordination issues and key threats including:
Ivory trafficking on the South Sudan boundary with DRC (especially Garamba NP ) and Central Africa Republic (CAR)
Chimpanzee trafficking
Commercial bushmeat trafficking on the South Sudan DRC border
At individual levels, targeted training seasons have been undertaken on different occasions for 5 staffs of the Wildlife Crime unit and Wildlife Security personnel deployed at the Juba Airport focusing on Law Enforcement Monitoring (LEM), anti-trafficking and identification of wildlife contraband passing through key exit routes. This is built on training of Trainers sessions conducted earlier focusing on the basics application and effective use of equipment. Selected personnel from key departments at the central Ministry have benefited from the training. The departments of Wildlife management, research, wildlife crime unit and unit of natural resources and external relations are fully equipped with computers and other field equipment. 12 individuals participated in the training (4 from each of the following departments: Wildlife Management, Research and Wildlife Security and Crime Unit). The training provided practical training on the use of wildlife conservation and monitoring tools and equipment. The training covered a range of technical areas including: Introduction to data collection methods (use of datasheets and recording observations); techniques of protected areas management, and monitoring; Principles of reporting and using equipment (GPS, Camera, binoculars); Equipment care and maintenance; Demonstration and use of laptops, printers, GPS, hard drive and projector setup; Reporting of wildlife sightings for protected areas management and monitoring, introduction to the use of field guides; building protected area report; applications and use of maps, compass, tents, binoculars and other field equipment. At institutional level, various equipment and conservation tools were deployed to strengthen the key departments of the Ministry, which play key role in the development of the protected area network across the country with the technical support of WCS. Plans are underway to conduct an additional training for the tourism department to use media tools for information dissemination.

description.narrative: METT scores for the four key PAs Southern NP Zeraf GR Badingilo NP Boma NP

comment.narrative: There is improved management capacity for protected area management and monitoring of threats. Several training of park staffs have been undertaken in Boma, Badingilo and Southern parks. A great deal of park management infrastructures such as park headquarters, ranger posts and administrative blocks have been developed, inspected and cleared of structural deficiencies and approve for operations. WCS continues to provide technical and logistical support to park wardens of Boma, Badingilo, Southern and Lantoto national parks focusing on addressing the continued threats to elephant security and trafficking of live wildlife and related products. Effective anti-poaching operations and wildlife security surveillance has been ongoing to monitor and control the borders of South Sudan and DRC as well as along the roads leading to Rumbek Improvements in management support, staff training and infrastructure development have been made in Badingilo and Southern national parks and other areas in SNP and in wildlife corridors proposed for construction of ranger posts have been identified. Security issues have prevented undertaking construction in SNP. Security situations have curtailed efforts to develop Zeraf game reserve. Conservation activities have been scaled up in Boma park. METT scores for Badingilo park is 66, Boma 64 and 54 for SNP.

description.narrative: Capacity building for protected area management improved
Encroachment of PA estate reduced

comment.narrative: Significant encroachment rates in several key PAs and key wildlife corridors
Strategies to address encroachment designed and implemented and encroachment rates reduced

WCS lobbied through key government ministries and institutions including Ministry of Environment, Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry and the executive wing of the Natural Resource Management Group (NRMG) to halt construction of a road that dissects Badingilo Park diagonally and called for the need to conduct environmental impact assessment (EIA). The finding of the study was to inform the decision-making process and move forward with the road construction. The Council of Ministers unanimously passed 3 key resolutions directing the immediate halting of the road construction, and directed alternative route to be constructed outside the northern boundary of Badingilo National Park as proposed; handover of SPLA's military academy constructed inside Badingilo National Park boundaries to South Sudan National Wildlife Service and dredging of seasonal streams to retain enough water for wildlife during dry seasons. This was a great achievement for conservation as encroachment pressure on the park coming from the army units along the park is greatly lessened. The project has supported and facilitated the holding of a one day public lecture in Juba Bridge Hotel by the NRMG under the theme: Environmental Governance and Natural Resource Enhancement. This important event was attended by high profile government officials and was used as a forum to call for sound development and planning processes and practices that take on board environmental considerations. Strategies and measures are in place to address encroachment into key protected areas, including monitoring and halting logging for timber in Southern National Park. Road patrols and regular aerial monitoring of threats are being undertaken over relatively secured areas (outside war zones) of Badingilo, Boma and Southern parks.

description.narrative: Protected area network strategic plan adopted and implemented (conforming to IUCN criteria and wildlife requirements)

comment.narrative: No plan exists
Plan adopted and in place.

The GIS teams, in collaboration with the Wildlife Service, used historic documents and other resources to update the maps of the protected areas of South Sudan. The PAs of South Sudan are now assigned appropriate IUCN categories, following a request by the UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre. The updated maps were submitted to the World Database of Protected Areas and were presented at the IUCN World Parks Congress, in Sydney, 12-19 November 2014. The inclusion of the protected areas of South Sudan in the global-level conservation estates is a reflection of the countrys commitment to biodiversity conservation and protected area management.The data collection and analyses for developing a strategic plan and fully integrate the PAs of South Sudan into a landscape-wide approach is underway. A technical committee composed of members from WCS and the Wildlife Service has been constituted to initiate the process for the development of the PA Strategic Plan.

description.narrative: Policy regulations necessary for guidance of PA network management.

comment.narrative:
*Wildlife Policy drafted and awaiting adoption
*Wildlife Law under revision drafted
*Tourism Policy drafted and awaiting adoption

*Wildlife and Tourism Policies adopted
*Wildlife law revised and adopted
*Tourism law designed and adopted

The Technical Committee composed of members from the Ministry and WCS have completed reviewing and updating the draft of Wildlife Conservation and Protected Areas Bill, 2015 and the Tourism Bill, 2015. The Ministry of Justice has also completed reviewing both of the Bills and has forwarded them to the Council of Ministers after which they will be sent to the South Sudan Legislative Assembly (SSLA) for discussions. Both Bills are comprehensive enough to capture fairly the full range of trends that are witnessed in wildlife legislation across Africa, including integration of international conventions, provisions for various forms of utilization, promotion of eco-tourism activities and concessions in protected areas and provisions for establishment of conservancies by communities among other provisions. The Tourism Strategy (Masterplan) for South Sudan has been drafted and adopted. Three Tourism Regulations have been drafted and adopted including Tourism in Protected Areas, Hotel Standards and Licensing and Tourism Training college regulations.

description.narrative: Percentage of staffing with competencies and skills matching position requirements and with clear job description.

comment.narrative:
10 % of MWCT staff have competencies and skills matching clearly defined position requirements:
WCS has been working with the Wildlife Service of the Ministry of Interior and Wildlife Conservation as well as the Directorate of Tourism to identify key technical staffs from various departments including from states in South Sudan. This has drawn in personnel from Wildlife Management, Research, Wildlife Crime and Natural Resources and External Relations departments. Three different technical committees have been constituted to undertake drafting and reviews of various conservation strategy documents with facilitation by WCS's conservation experts. These committees include Wildlife/Tourism Policies, laws and regulations, protected area planning and Law Enforcement technical teams. The establishment of the various committees to deal with various conservation aspects and programs is part of the capacity building initiative aimed at providing on the job-training opportunities for team members as the committees work with WCS's international conservation consultants and experts to develop the planning and key management and strategy documents. the team members have been exposed to principles of drafting of wildlife policies, laws and regulations, tourism masterplans, general management plans for protected areas, aerial surveys and development of law enforcement strategies. As a key outcome of these exposures, some of these documents have been recently reviewed or updated to take into account the conservation challenges facing South Sudan following the outbreak of the current war in the country without any support from international consultants.

description.narrative: Communications strategy

comment.narrative: No communications strategy. Occasional media engagement.

Communications strategy in place, implementation underway.
Regular activities to raise awareness using various media.

The South Sudan Tourism Communications Strategy is currently in place. The communications strategy has been drafted, adopted and integrated into the Tourism Materplan 2015. The communications strategy, currently being implemented, is helping to raise the profile of the country's wildlife, natural and cultural resources and promote opportunities for tourism investment in the country. The strategy has a three year action plan. The WCS's News from the Bush Newsletter has been conceived as part of the implementation of this strategy to communicate tourism prospects and conservation challenges, including tracking the achievements of the Wildlife Service. Following the security challenges in the country, efforts are directed at raising awareness on the increased poaching and trafficking of live wildlife and wildlife products. National and international media outlets are constantly being engaged by the Wildlife Service and WCS to disseminate this information.

description.narrative: Number of viewer visits to Website site.

comment.narrative: Website exists from 2007- out of date and no system in place to manage site
Website functional and attracting viewers. System in place to maintain and regularly update website.

The Tourism website was developed through the funding support from UNDP/GEF project back in 2013. However, the site could not be launched due to the splitting of the Ministry of Wildlife Conservation and Tourism (MWCT) and annexing of the Directorates to separate ministries of Interior and Agriculture, respectively. Nonetheless, with current move to bring together the departments, a way forward will be reached to operationalize the website to help promote South Sudans wealth of natural asset. Currently, the focal persons from Wildlife Education and Tourism Marketing departments have been identified and an office space has been allocated for developing conservation education materials and information following a presidential degree in March 2014 which created the Ministry of Tourism and Wildlife Conservation. The website which was designed for the whole Ministry is set to be operational upon appointment of a Minister for the Ministry.

description.narrative: Site management of four key protected areas strengthened
Levels of illegal hunting of key and endangered wildlife species in target PAs

comment.narrative: Significant commercial poaching occuring in each of the four PAs
Poaching levels reduced by 50% for key and endangered wildlife species below baseline levels at project start

With funding support of GEF/UNDP, WCS has greatly strengthened the monitoring and law enforcement capacity of the Wildlife forces in the Lantoto National Park to effectively monitor illegal transboundary activities at the border with DRC. 5 poachers from South Sudan were apprehended by the Wildlife Service of South Sudan after the DRC wildlife forces tipped off the movement of these poachers to their counterpart. Yei County Court in South Sudan sentenced the 5 poachers to imprisonment ranging from six months to two years. The court also ordered the confiscation of the exhibits and to be handed them over to Wildlife Service in Yei County. This trial marks a positive step in setting a legal precedence for dealing with poachers and will help in boosting and reaching conclusive law enforcement efforts.
In efforts to provide additional information to help in identifying seized ivory and determine the pattern of illegal trading nodes and networks of ivory smugglers, WCS in cooperation with the Wildlife Service, facilitated the exportation of South Sudans elephant hair samples to the University of Washington in the United States for scientific analysis in 2015. The samples was sent for scientific purposes aimed at undertaking DNA analysis and building of elephant DNA database to help in the identification of the origins of elephant contraband as a joint effort to combat the growing illegal elephant poaching and ivory trafficking around the world. Efforts are underway to create Dog Detection (K9) unit to help in identification of wildlife contraband. WCS and the Ministry collaborated with Prof. Axel through the Giraffe Conservation Foundation to undertake the identification of the giraffe subspecies. In total, 4 giraffe skin samples were analyzed and the preliminary results show that the giraffes found on the West bank of the Nile are Kordofan giraffe subspecies (G.c. antiquorum) while the giraffes found on the East of the Nile are Rotschilds giraffe subspecies. Giraffe in South Sudan are experiencing increased poaching threats. The knowledge about the conservation status of these subspecies will inform the development of strategies for their protection.
The joint team of WCS aviation and protected area management/Law enforcement monitoring staffs continue to undertake regular aerial reconnaissance over protected areas (Badingilo, Boma, Southern, and Shambe parks) and aimed at gathering information on incidences of poaching of elephants, commercial bushmeat hunting, and trafficking in ivory, bushmeat and live wildlife species, and other illegal activities including infrastructure development such as roads and charcoal production activities in efforts to design strategies for addressing these threats.

description.narrative: Number of management plans and preliminary management strategies

comment.narrative: Boma management plan drafting underway
- Boma and Badingilo management plans adopted implementation underway - Zeraf and Southern preliminary management strategies adopted and implementation underway

The Badingilo Management Plan has been reviewed and the final draft has been completed awaiting stakeholders' consultations. WCS protected area management expert has been facilitating the reviewing of the draft management plan. A concept note detailing out the stakeholders consultation process has been developed and communications have been initiated with the office of the Governor of Central Equatoria State to seek his availability and members of the state cabinet ministers for the meeting. A similar meeting will be rolled out to Jongeli and Eastern Equatoria state before organizing a larger forum with grassroots. The completed Southern National Park headquarters has received office supplies and equipment to fully furnish the SNP Park Headquarters. During this trip, office and food supplies, internet equipment, and furniture, construction materials and wildlife conservation books were delivered to operationalize the headquarter facility.

description.narrative:
Boma and Badingilo NP gazetted
Zeraf GR extended
Percentage of boundaries of the 4 PAs demarcated

comment.narrative:
Boma boundaries proposed in early 1980s.
Badingilo boundaries proposed in 1980s.
No PA boundaries demarcated.
All PA boundaries demarcated, including Zeraf extension.

The data and information on ecological processes and socio-economic dynamics of Badingilo, Boma, Southern Parks, Zeraf Game Reserve and other protected areas in the country are up to date. Beginning from 2007, years of aerial surveys of wildlife, livestock and human activity, data from recce flights and movement of radio-collared species, socio-economic surveys and land cover maps have all provided a clear understanding of the ecological processes, patterns and parks resources. These key areas are already mapped and the maps showing park extensions modeled on the basis of the data have been discussed and conceptually adopted by the Wildlife Service. Some park signs have been deployed in Boma, Badingilo and Southern Parks in accessible areas. However, the security situation following the outbreak of the ongoing conflict stalled ground truthing move and erection of boundary signs in some areas and legal adoption of the extensions.

description.narrative: Number of km patrolled (and associated catch per unit effort and encounter rate data) by wildlife forces and coverage by aerial patrols

comment.narrative: [none]
[none]

Law enforcement monitoring systems have been put in place to monitor, document and report threats to key protected areas sites including Boma, Badingilo, Southern, Lantoto, Shambe parks and Zeraf Game Reserve and other protected areas in the country. Since the start of the project extensive areas have been covered by aerial, vehicle and foot patrols in efforts to document conservation threats. To date, 113, 833.5 km aerial patrols, 47,329 km covered by vehicle patrol and 17,663 foot patrol coverage. The patrol efforts have been boosted by establishment of protected area infrastructures including wildlife headquarters, administrative units and ranger posts and the deployment of GPS, Cameras and communication equipment in key PAs and wildlife corridors.

description.narrative: Number of times PA authorities meet with stakeholders at local levels

comment.narrative:
Occasional at Boma
None at other sites
Coordination mechanisms establish and meet regularly

The WCS's staff from the socio-economic department conducted conservation outreach activities with the communities in Lafon Payam in 2015 as part of the efforts to continue building on the established stakeholder coordination mechanism. Work with the community has been further strengthened as WCS identified a local CBO, PDCO to implement small grant livelihoods project with the Lafon communities. The PDCO together with WCSs socioeconomic and livelihoods team conducted a conservation livelihoods baseline survey with sampled communities of Lafon located on the eastern sector of Badingilo park.

description.narrative: Number of partnership agreements between PA adjacent local communities and PA management

comment.narrative: In addition to two CBOs, the CEPO and ART that were sub-granted to implement the conservation focused WCS Livelihoods Small Grants Programme with counterpart funding (USAID), WCS conducted an Organizational Capacity Assessment (OCA) in Lafon Administrative Area in Eastern Equatorial State (EES) and in Juba County in Central Equatorial State (CES) to identify potential and credible Community Based Organizations (CBOs), during which the Peace and Development Collaborative Organization (PDCO) operating in Central Equatorial State (CES) was found to have the needed capacity to undertake the task. An agreement has been signed with the PDCO on condition that it hires and trains members of the Pari community in Lafon area as beneficiaries in the implementation of the project. A process is underway to enlist one more CBO from Boma area to expand the engagement with communities.

description.narrative: Number of pilot ecotourism projects established

comment.narrative: The development of the countrys rich wildlife resources, including the protected areas to provide opportunities for investment in eco-tourism business remains an integral part of WCSs interventions with funding support from GEF/UNDP and the USAID matching fund. Many areas with nature-based tourism potentials have already been identified and mapped across the country. Contacts with potential tour operators have been made in the past years and these contacts are still be maintained and will be engaged with when security situations normalize to encourage investment in eco-tourism projects. As the security situations could not provide space operating tourism business in key protected areas of South Sudan, significant efforts have been deployed in developing the enabling environment including, tourism policy, law and regulations.

description.narrative: Sustainable financing options for protected areas initiated
Number of sustainable financing mechanisms identified and designed

comment.narrative: 3 as part of overall strategy outline

WCS continues to review internally a variety of innovative financing mechanisms exploring options to secure sustainable funding for South Sudans PAs. At the site level, though limited, protected area user fees are still the most important source of revenue. Except Nimule National Park receiving limited visitors, many PA sites face security challenges to allow for normal operation of tourism businesses. The sources of funding have already been identified including local (e.g. user fees, sponsorship, donations); national (e.g. taxes and charges, endowment funds, incentives); and international (bilateral and multilateral donors and lending agencies and organizations).The right to biological prospecting within PAs by multinational drug companies has raised significant funds in some countries and this could be explored together with opportunities for raising funds through debt-for-nature swaps.

description.narrative: Number of business plans developed for the 4 targeted areas

comment.narrative: An assessment of the South Sudan protected areas resources have been undertaken over the years through extended surveys. However, the plan to market these resources to meet financial needs of the Pas across the country has been stalled due to ongoing insecurity. At a site level, through management planning process, the financing needs including revenue and expenditure of the Badingilo Park has been undertaken covering 5 years from 2016-2020 and some viable funding sources to meet these needs with clear estimation of program costs have been identified and incorporated into the plan. This exercise will inform the development of detailed business plans for all the sites.

description.narrative: Total operational budget (including HR and capital budget) allocation (US$) for protected area management

comment.narrative: 40 million US$
Increasing with significant allocations to PA management
N/A - Relevant activities are scheduled to commence in subsequent years

description.narrative: Number of private sector actors participating in partnerships

comment.narrative: Nimule National Park has been receiving limited visitors as the area is relatively stable. Currently, the Bigfoot Tours have expressed interests in running a tourism business in the park. A process is underway to advertise for an expression of interests for a competitive process. WCS will also continue to maintain contacts with established eco-tourism companies, extractive industries and individuals with potentials to invest in the tourism sector or enter into partnerships. This engagement will continue as the security situations in the country improve.

ECC responded to 6,385 calls, including 306 for SGBV and 1,266 for medical emergencies. 4. 46.34% (14.8% female) of police personnel have been verified.

Juba ECC operational and establishment of Wau ECC is ongoing. 161 (24 female) police personnel from Wau were trained in ECC services. 4. 23% of police personnel have been issued ID cards.
